III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
The Audere Home is located in a two-story building with a walkout basement. The
twelve-bed facility is located in Kentwood, Michigan off a main street that is across
from their main Wedgwood facility location. This allows this facility to be
completely separated from the other secure licensed facilities located on
Wedgwood Campus to offer the youth a feeling of a true step-down program.
Upon arrival at the facility, there is a designated parking lot and beautiful
landscaping to make the facility look like it blends in with the surrounding
apartment complexes.
Upon walking through the front door, there is a main lobby where there is a staff
desk area to greet visitors. Once at the main desk area, there is a main hallway
leading to each opposite side of the house. To the left of the main desk area there
is a community area that is furnished with a TV, couches, and individual chairs on
one side of the room. There is also a storage closet and lockers where staff or
youth can keep their personal items. On the opposite side of the room there is a
room with a door that is set up for the youth to use as a video game area. At the
end of the left side of the first floor there is an exit door and another office space
that will be used for the case manager.
Once back to the main entrance desk area to the right hallway, there is a doorway
to the left that leads to the finished basement area. Also, on the left-hand side
there is a bathroom that youth will be able to use when they are on the first floor.
On the right side of the hallway there is an area where there will be a community
phone for the youth to use where they can sit at a desk. This is right next to the
staff desk area, so if there needs to be supervised phone calls that can be
completed. Further down the hallway to the left is the dining area where there are
tables and chairs set up for the youth to eat at. Off the dining room area there is
an exit door that leads to an outdoor patio area on a deck with a staircase that
leads to the basketball court. To the right of the dining room there is another
hangout area where the youth will be able to socialize and utilize the air hockey
table. This hangout area also has bay windows that show a lot of natural light. At
the end of this hallway is the kitchen area. The kitchen has two stoves, two ovens,
two dishwashers, a sink, two refrigerators, and a pantry area. This will be a great
area for the youth to learn life skills in cooking.
When headed downstairs off this main hallway area, it leads to a walk out
basement. Within this area there is a lot of space for the youth to hang out in.
There are also two staff offices that will be located down there and three
storage/supply closets. The home supervisor and activity specialist will have their
offices located down here. There is also the location of the locked utility closet. A
bathroom located in the basement. The basement again is surrounded by multiple
windows to allow natural light. There are two exit doors in the basement that lead
to the basketball court. When exiting the basement to the right side of the main
3

entrance, there is a separate entrance to another part of the building. This area
will be utilized as a space for youth to have visits in private. The door is locked
from the outside, but youth will be able to exit on their own. This main area has
another fridge, pantry, couches, a table and set of chairs. There is a bathroom
located in this area as well. There are two staff offices located in this space that
will remain locked.
When heading back to the main entrance, this is where youth will be able to
access the bedrooms on the second floor. To the left and right of the main
doorway area there are doors that are locked which lead to the bedroom hallways.
This allows the youth’s bedrooms to be safe and monitored. Each door leads to
either the male or female side of the building. Youth are able to exit from upstairs
on their own. Both hallways mirror one another with a staff office that is located
between the hallways which again allows the female and male youth to be
separated. The staff office is a locked area that the youth cannot enter but staff
will be able to have access to both sides of the hallway and keep medications
locked. The staff office is where third shift staff will remain to ensure that
bedrooms and bathrooms are monitored appropriately. Each hallway has its own
laundry room that is located at the top of the stairs. Within each laundry room the
youth will have access to use the washer and dryer. There is another locked
pantry in the laundry rooms where the locked chemicals will be kept for safety.
Each hallway consists of five bedrooms where there will be one bedroom that has
two beds, and the four other rooms will be single bedrooms. This allows up to six
youth to stay in each hallway, where each youth will have their own bed to sleep
in. Each bedroom has its own window to allow for natural light. Each of the
hallways consists of having two bathrooms which means there are four bathrooms
in total in the main sleeping area. Each bedroom hallway has its own emergency
exit where youth can leave the area without staff needing to unlock a door. There
are cameras located throughout the home to monitor the youth. There are no
cameras located in the bedrooms or bathrooms.
An onsite walkthrough of the facility was completed on 08/13/2025.
The Fire Inspection was completed on 08/05/2025 stating Final Approval.
The Health Inspection was completed on 07/14/2025 and received an A rating.
B. Program Description
The Audere Home is a specialized open mental health behavioral integration co-
ed residential treatment program for youth transitioning from residential to
independent living. The facility is licensed for males and females, ages 10-17
years old, with a capacity of twelve youth. Youth may be admitted before the age
of 18 but must discharge from the program before turning 19 years old. The length
of stay for this program is 6-12 months depending on the individual youth’s
transition plans.
4

Per the agency’s program statement, the scope of practice/admission criteria for
this license is as follows: “The Audere Home is to help youth who have completed
the treatment in an MHBS setting and/or are in the foster care setting but needing
additional supports before moving into a traditional independent living placement.
There is additional focus on the building of independence skills within a highly
supportive environment. There are many youth that require assistance with the
transition from residential setting into less restrictive placement and the program
will offer a community integrated, independent living focused treatment milieu to
aid clients in developing skills of daily living and tasks associated with preparation
for an additionally less restrictive level of care. Program staff work closely with
each individual client to develop a treatment plan according to their individualized
needs. This will be an open residential and treatment programming necessitates
safe daily community integration.”
The program will work with youth to incorporate a variety of interventions to build
a healthy skillset including leisure skills, commitment to academics, applying for
jobs and maintaining a work ethic, personal schedule maintenance, budgeting and
financial literacy, healthy relationships, personal hygiene and household tasks,
community engagement, and self-reliance and self-advocacy. The license will
assign multiple workers to be involved in the youth’s treatment, including a
Masters-Level Clinician, Case Manager, Home Supervisor, an assigned Goal
Worker, Youth Treatment Specialist, Registered Nurse, Physician Assistant, and
Psychiatrist. The program emphasizes Trauma Informed Treatment that focuses
on understanding the neurological, biological, psychological, and social effects of
trauma and the prevalence of these experiences in people who seek and receive
mental health services. The clinicians are trained to provide a client-centered
approach which incorporates elements of various treatment modalities. The
program case manager will oversee the development and the implementation of
the youth’s treatment plan and coordination with the youth’s care team. The
program will utilize CASEY, ACE, TSQ and other assessment skills to develop an
individualized plan to capitalize on strengths to compensate for skills deficits in
preparation for independent living. These assessments are completed within 7
days of intake and on a 90-day schedule until the youth is discharged from the
program.
The staff-to-resident ratio is 1:4 during waking hours and 1:6 during sleeping
hours. The facility will have no form of seclusions for the youth. Facility staff will
be trained in the use of AEGIS System for crisis prevention, de-escalation, and
emergency restraint purposes. The AEGIS System focuses on prevention of
dysregulation in youth and provides for the least restrictive therapeutic holds when
there is an emergency restraint needed.
